sentences_tone.text: Zynga's Window Is Closing - Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA) | Seeking AlphaSign in / Join NowGO»Market NewsStock IdeasDividendsMarket OutlookInvesting StrategyETFs & FundsEarningsPROLong IdeasShort IdeasCramer's PicksIPOsQuick PicksSectorsEditor's PicksZynga's Window Is ClosingNov.

6.16 | About: Zynga (ZNGA) Vince Martin Follow Long/short equity, value, gamblingSend MessageSummaryEven as a long-time Zynga bear, I can see some small reasons for optimism in the Q3 report.CSR2 has shown some early strength, there may be more room to cut costs and improve margins, and it certainly sounds as if the grownups are in charge.Still, Zynga remains sharply unprofitable, and there is a lot of pressure on Dawn of Titans.If DoT isn't a massive hit, Zynga's story looks very weak come 1H 2017; even a big success already looks priced in.Zynga's (NASDAQ:ZNGA) third-quarter report was a bit of a mixed bag, in my opinion, and the market's reaction seemed to support that interpretation.
Shares fell after-hours, rebounded to gains Thursday morning, and then gave most of those gains back by the end of the session.
That makes some sense: Q3 strikes me as the type of quarter which bulls and bears alike can argue supports their respective cases.
As a long-time ZNGA bear (and an investor short the stock through put options), I will admit to seeing some positive takeaways from the quarter.
CSR2 seems to have done well in its launch, advertising growth is solid, and CEO Frank Gibeau seems a noted change from past management in terms of honesty and competence.
Still, overall I see Q3 as another step towards a rather bearish outcome for ZNGA shares.

The bullish "story" here for some time has been that CSR2 and Dawn of Titans, both from the acquired NaturalMotion studio, in concert with an operational "turnaround" will radically change the earnings profile of the company and support what it is an extremely high valuation at the moment (by any measure).
With DoT being launched in Q4, we're now about six months from that story playing out.
And, modest optimism aside, once that story ends, the new Zynga "story" looks highly likely to disappoint.

The case I've made going back to early last year is that even if both games are huge hits, their success already is priced in; I thought Q3 supported that thesis for a number of reasons: 1. Profits haven't really improved that much.
Zynga changed its Adjusted EBITDA methodology in response to SEC guidance; the company no longer excludes deferred revenue changes from its calculation.
That change dramatically affects comparisons: on the old methodology, Adjusted EBITDA is up over 160% year over year through the first nine months; under the new calculation, it's been halved.
In fairness to Zynga, the exclusion of deferred revenue makes some sense, as it better lines up costs and expenses in the same period.
(Though it also implies far worse profit performance this year.)
And regardless of the EBITDA methodology, it certainly does look like the business has improved year to date, somewhat.

Using the high end of Q4 guidance (it certainly looks like Zynga is sandbagging of late), full-year bookings (revenue plus changes in deferred revenue) are projected to increase almost 7% after sub-1% growth in 2015.
Opex (excluding an impairment charge this year) is down almost 13% YTD.
But neither bookings nor GAAP opex figures tell the whole story here.

Bookings and revenue figures are inflated by the continuing shift to mobile: $1 spent on mobile is booked as $1 in revenue, but $1 spent on Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) is booked at just $0.70 (net of the 30% fee Facebook takes).

The substantial shift toward mobile probably accounts for roughly half the year-over-year bookings growth Zynga will post this year (the Q3 10-Q hasn't been filed, but in Q2, Facebook's share of bookings went from 31% to 19%, which implies a 3%+ tailwind).

And it's not as if the incremental $0.30 benefits profits; in fact, higher mobile payment fees were cited as the primary reason for the decline in Q3 Adjusted EBITDA year over year under the old methodology.
Meanwhile, adjusted opex (backing out the same items Zynga does in calculating Adjusted EBITDA) actually is up year over year, by a little over 1 percent.

To be fair, that will mitigate somewhat: Q3 figures were inflated by spending behind product launches (with a 7% Q/Q increase attributed in the Q3 earnings letter to the launches of CSR2 and FarmVille: Tropic Escape.
And Gibeau did say in the Q&A of the Q3 conference call that there was more room to improve operating margins, to get them in line with that of peers.
But it doesn't appear that Gibeau, at least, is projecting further headcount reductions or a radical change in the operating structure.
He mentioned "redeployment" and increased efficiency in R&D and G&A spend - but R&D spend already has been on a multi-year decline since 2011.
And the CEO also admitted that Zynga needed more breakout hits - something that will be more difficult, albeit not impossible, with lower spend.
The overall point is that from a P&L perspective, Zynga doesn't look all that much different than it did twelve months ago.
Adjusted EBITDA for the year is guided to $54 million (under the new calculation; ~$61 million under the old).
At $2.76, the company's fully diluted market cap is $2.68 billion (remember, there are ~90 million shares excluded from the Q3 count as anti-dilutive) and its enterprise value is about $1.8 billion.

That leaves ZNGA trading at about 33x on an EV/EBITDA basis: about double the multiple Caesars Entertainment (NASDAQ:CZR) and Caesars Acquisition (NASDAQ:CACQ) received for Caesars Interactive, a business with much better margins and much better growth than Zynga.
Meanwhile, the Adjusted EBITDA figures exclude share-based compensation, which, in the case of Zynga, is a huge issue.
That compensation is guided to about $110 million this year, more than offsetting that pre-tax profit.
Free cash flow through nine months was $25 million; the company issued $81 million worth of options and restricted stock over the same time.

For any bulls excited about the $200 million repurchase announced, at the current pace every dollar will go to employees - and Zynga's share count would actually end up higher at the end of those two years.
The issue for years now has been that Zynga's business is destroying, not creating, shareholder value.
The cash balance has fallen by a billion dollars, the share count has increased, and the stock has continued to decline over the long term (though it has performed well year to date).
That's still the case: Zynga's ROE and ROIC are negative when accounting for the substantial shareholder dilution.
While there's been some changes under Gibeau, and some modest improvements, that core problem still hasn't changed.
And it leaves the company once again looking to the future - and the stock once again pricing in a good deal of success.
2. CSR2 and Dawn of Titans need to be smash hits.
CSR2 appears to have generated somewhere around $18 million in bookings in Q3; Zynga attributed a ~$20 million sequential increase "primarily" to CSR2.
The company also forecast a step down in CSR2 bookings in Q4.
A 7% increase Q/Q in non-GAAP opex, or about $8 million, was attributed to increased market spend for CSR2 and Tropic Escape, and Zynga's gross margin YTD is about 68%.

So CSR2 in 2017 might be expected to drive $70 million in revenue - aggressively, assuming a rebound in bookings - or about $50 million in gross profit (again, aggressively, assuming it has a higher gross margin than the company as a whole; given its heavy mobile usage, that's unlikely).
Annual marketing spend might be as much as $20 million, assuming a pullback after launch (and including some form of stock-based compensation, which is excluded from non-GAAP numbers).
Even excluding incremental expenses, CSR2 maybe is contributing an incremental $30 million in annual EBITDA - and that looks aggressive.
All else equal, that's an incremental $15-20 million next year - for a company that is losing $56 million in 2016.
To get ZNGA to a single-digit EV/EBITDA (accounting for dilution), all else equal, DoT would need to generate over $200 million in annual Adjusted EBITDA.

This is an argument that I've been making in some form for years, even going back to when Empires & Allies - now a troublesome "legacy mobile game", as Gibeau put it on the Q3 call - was a pillar of the bull case.
To support ZNGA's current valuation, Dawn of Titans needs to be one of the biggest hits of all time.

Even assuming the market ignores stock comp (as it seemingly does with a number of tech companies), DoT still needs to get close to $100 million in pre-tax profit, getting the consolidated figure to the $175 million range and the reported EV/Adjusted EBITDA multiple to <10x.
For what it's worth, Activision Blizzard (NASDAQ:ATVI) bought King for 6.5x EBITDA and Churchill Downs (NASDAQ:CHDN) paid 8.5x for Big Fish Games.
And even that level of strength from DoT assumes the rest of the portfolio won't decline.
3. The portfolio ex-NaturalMotion is awful.
But it will decline.
Zynga itself said so in the Q3 earnings letter.

And one perhaps under-covered fact in Q3 was how poorly the legacy portfolio performed:
Click to enlarge
Source: Zynga earnings presentation Poker was flat year over year.
Wizard of Oz Slots declined double digits, while Hit it Rich!
shrunk by about one-third.
FarmVille 2 was halved; Country Escape did at least that badly.
E&A is a bust.
Beyond CSR2 and Dawn of Titans, this is not much of a portfolio.

The social slot business is being pressured - Big Fish bookings were down 8% - and is getting ridiculously competitive, with operators like Penn National Gaming (NASDAQ:PENN) and casino suppliers like International Game Technology (NYSE:IGT) investing in the space.

Words With Friends got a nice bump over last year's holiday season, but advertising bookings - a key driver this year - are guided to decline YOY in Q4, with the business not strong enough to lap the tougher comparison.
Zynga acquired Rising Tide Games last September; it again pulled down the contingent consideration liability in Q3, as the Black Diamond Casino product looks like a disappointment.
There's going to be a significant offset to whatever success DoT and CSR2 can drive in declines in the rest of the business.

And there is no evidence that Zynga can develop new games; Gibeau already seemed to be talking down expectations for next year's slate, and the company itself hasn't developed a hit of any kind since the FarmVille/Mafia Wars/Zynga Poker days.
CSR2 and DoT were acquired - and delayed - as was Words With Friends.
E&A was a bust, as was Looney Tunes Dash!.
Gibeau said on the Q3 call that the company needed to focus on hitting timeline targets: "There's nothing that drives costs higher than missing dates on products".
But the presentation disclosed that "several new features" for Zynga Poker - again, the company's highest-grossing game - were pushed into Q4.
This doesn't necessarily lay at the feet of Gibeau, who simply hasn't been CEO long enough to change the culture.

Chairman Mark Pincus' second stint included a notable change to team sizes that he championed, and that appears - given the myriad delays in developments - to have been a poor decision, and possibly a disastrous one.
Turnover has been ridiculous: 56% of employees had been with the company for less than two years as of year-end 2015, per the 10-K.
And Gibeau interestingly argued that the company was underpenetrated in Asia, in particular, with that statement coming less than two years after Zynga closed its studio in China.
But the broader point is that Zynga ex-NaturalMotion simply is very poor at the job of developing mobile games.
In five years, it's put out only failures and new versions of existing IP (its own in FarmVille, that of others in social casino).
I can see some interest in a potential turnaround here - but so much of a turnaround already is priced in.

Valuation Right now, if an investor gave Zynga credit for $60 million in Adjusted EBITDA, ignored dilution, and added $0.25 per share for the real estate (a rough estimate of the value of the headquarters less the loss of subleasing revenue and the cost of new digs), at a 10x multiple (again, above most peers save for Caesars Interactive), ZNGA would be worth about $1.80 per share - a roughly 35% downside.

It is clear that there is a substantial amount of improvement from DoT, in particular, that is priced in, and likely from other moves, whether additional cost-cutting or improved margins as older games go into run-off mode.
The problem is that there are declines coming beyond the NaturalMotion games - and there should be little confidence that 2017's slate is going to contain any games that can be major hits.
(Certainly, none have been discussed or have the multi-year development timeline for CSR2 or DoT.)
So looking ahead to Zynga's Q4 and Q1 releases, there is going to be substantial pressure on DoT, in particular.
And if Zynga misses expectations on the game at all, the downside should be swift and severe.

Even if DoT can add $40 million in profit - a decent result - 2017 Adjusted EBITDA at a more normalized high-single digit/low-double digit multiple still only gets the stock into the low $2 range - and that, again, assumes the market simply ignores share-based comp.
And a 10-12x multiple might be aggressive; after the DoT launch, Zynga's bull case is out of ammo.
From there, Zynga "is what it is", so to speak - and barring a drastic change in the next two quarters, that seems unlikely to satisfy the market.
So out of the quarter, even with some modest good news (and I will admit that it does seem like the grownups finally are in charge), I see little to change my long-held bearishness toward ZNGA.

Because I don't believe the core story has changed here much: this is a still a poorly-executing company with an abysmal history of internal development that is reliant on two games to support its valuation.
And with the declines in the legacy games accelerating, the margin for error coming out of Q3 looks even slimmer than it did heading into the quarter.
Cash and real estate don't make a bull case, particularly for a company with no interest in using either resource aggressively or effectively.
ZNGA investors still are buying a business - and that business isn't a good one.
If DoT fails, or even disappoints, that will be abundantly clear in a few short months.
Disclosure: I am/we are short ZNGA.
I wrote this article myself, and it expresses my own opinions.
